text.p: FRONT PAGE POLITICAL NEWS.
RZECZPOSPOLITA

- Over 70 percent of Poles blame the ruling coalition of the ex-communist Democratic Left Alliance (SLD) and the Polish Peasants Party (PSL) for negligence which enhanced the tragic consequences of floods in southern Poland, a survey by the Rzeczpospolita daily said.

- Around 26 percent of Poles are ready to vote for the SLD in the coming parliamentary elections, 25 percent favour the opposition right-wing Solidarity Electoral Action (AWS), 13 percent of the voters will vote for the centrist Union for Freedom (UW) while 10 percent favour the nationalist right-wing Movement for the Reconstruction of Poland (ROP), a July survey by the PBS polling institute said.

- Poland should join the social fund of the Council of Europe as soon as possible to obtain low interest long-term credits for the reconstruction of areas damaged by floods, the Union for Freedom (UW) demanded on Wednesday.

- In the event of victory in parliamentary elections in September, the right-wing Solidarity Electoral Action (AWS) will not change Poland's foreign policy in any significant way and will co-operate with the current ex-communist President Aleksander Kwasniewski, AWS' front-line politician Maciej Jankowski said during talks with the Foreign Office in London on Wednesday.
ECONOMIC AND MARKET STORIES RZECZPOSPOLITA

- Poland's economy is now like a locomotive at full speed and even the floods will not halt it, the Finance Minister Marek Belka said. The flooded areas' reconstruction will be funded from resources saved in other sectors of economy and the public budget deficit will not increase. If need be the government will introduce an additional tax to finance the damages, Belka said.

- The Komertel digital satellite telephone operator gave up its Internet access as a result of a 1,200 percent price rise demanded by the Telekomunikacja Polska SA (TPSA), the state-owned telecoms monopolist, Komertel said.

- Poland's food prices in the second ten days of July declined by 0.2 percent compared with the first ten days and were 2.5 percent lower than in the second ten days of June, a report by the Central Statistical Office (GUS) said.
- The Polish State Railways (PKP) have contracted 52 wagons designed and made by the Hipolit Cegielski (HCP) works in Poznan, western Poland, to be delivered in the next five years, PKP said.

- Poland's urban areas of Warsaw, Poznan, Katowice, Krakow, Szczecin, Gdansk, Lodz and Wroclaw have attracted the biggest volume of direct foreign investments of all areas of the country, a study by the experts of the Gdansk market economy research institute said.

- The TPSA telecoms firm has licensed the privately-owned Srodkowo Zachodnie Telefony Polskie (S-ZTP) telephone operator to build an exchange in Konin, central Poland, to serve 4,500 telephone lines and concentrators which will further increase the number of lines by 4,000, TPSA said.

- The municipalities of Gdansk, Gdynia and Sopot have invested 32 million zlotys in an new passenger terminal at the Gdansk-Trojmiasto airport to come into operation in the next few days, the Gdansk Trojmiasto airport's deputy president Tomasz Kloskowski said.

- The sales of the state-owned Hortex vegetable and fruit processor reached 500 million zlotys in the last accounting year showing an over 40 percent growth compared with the year before, the firm said. In the next three years Hortex plans a share listing on the Warsaw bourse to be followed by listings on international capital markets.
- The Bank Pocztowy postal bank in Bydgoszcz, central Poland, earned a net profit of 2.84 million zlotys in the first half of 1997, the bank said.
- The Polish Development Bank (PBR) has contracted Boygues and Boygues Poland construction firms to design and construct the bank's headquarters in central Warsaw worth $24.683 million, PBR said.
DZIENNIK PRAWA I GOSPODARKI
- Poland's parliament has amended the insurance act on Wednesday which now gives greater powers to the Insurance Guarantee Fund (UFG).
GAZETA WYBORCZA
- The Union for Freedom (UW) has proposed a damage payment of 10,000 zlotys to all businesses hurt in recent floods, the UW parliamentary deputy Karol Dzialoszynski said.
PARKIET

- Orbis, which is Poland's biggest travel agency and hotel operator, has presented a share issue prospectus to the Polish Securities Commission (KPW) and plans a listing on the Warsaw bourse in the fourth quarter of 1997, the firm's deputy president Ireneusz Weglowski said.
